diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: An acute, febrile illness of unknown cause that primarily affects children. Major symptoms include fever, rash, swelling of hands and feet, irritation and reddening of the whites of the eyes, swollen lymph glands in the neck, and irritation and inflammation of the mouth, lips, and throat.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. It features a bright red rash that covers most of the body, a sore throat, and a high fever.

diagnoses.name: Toxic shock syndrome (TSS)
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections. Often associated with tampon use in young women, but it can affect anyone of any age. Symptoms include sudden high fever, low blood pressure, vomiting or diarrhea, rash, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome / Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Symptoms include flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters, then the top layer of the skin dies and sheds.

diagnoses.name: Drug reactions with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
diagnoses.description: A drug-induced condition characterized by extensive rash, fever, lymphadenopathy, hematologic abnormalities (such as eosinophilia), and involvement of internal organs.

diagnoses.name: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder caused by exotoxin-producing strains of Staphylococcus aureus. It is characterized by red blistering skin that looks like a burn or scald, often preceded by sore throat and conjunctivitis.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 infection (Fifth disease)
diagnoses.description: A mild rash illness caused by parvovirus B19. It's more common in children than in adults. A bright red rash on the cheeks is a distinguishing symptom, followed by a more generalized rash that fades into a lace-like pattern.

diagnoses.name: Hand, foot, and mouth disease
diagnoses.description: A mild, contagious viral infection common in young children, characterized by sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection that's serious for small children but is easily preventable by a vaccine. The disease spreads through the air by respiratory droplets produced from coughing or sneezing. Symptoms include fever, cough, runny nose, inflamed eyes, and a red, blotchy skin rash.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis (Mono)
diagnoses.description: Commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, mono is a viral infection that causes symptoms such as fatigue, sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug reactions (e.g., drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms [DRESS] syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Urinary tract infection (UTI) with systemic symptoms
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues of the body causing symptoms like pericardial effusion, autoimmune hemolysis, and synovitis. Neuropsychiatric SLE can manifest with psychosis and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily affecting joints causing synovitis, rheumatoid arthritis can have systemic manifestations including pericardial effusion. Rarely, it might be associated with autoimmune hemolysis and neurological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This is a systemic autoimmune disease that shares characteristics of three other conditions: SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, and can show symptoms such as pericardial effusion, synovitis, and rare hemolytic anemia. Neurological symptoms including psychosis and seizures can occur.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis and/or pregnancy-related complications and associated with antibodies against phospholipids. It can coexist with other autoimmune disorders and, in rare cases, lead to neurological manifestations such as seizures, and hematologic abnormalities including hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily affecting exocrine glands, Sjögren's syndrome might have systemic manifestations including pericardial effusion and rare neurological complications. Hematologic abnormalities such as autoimmune hemolysis are uncommon but possible.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This is a rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. It can lead to symptoms like pericardial effusion and might involve neurological symptoms (neuro-Behçet's), although seizures are uncommon. Autoimmune hemolysis and synovitis are not typically associated but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, mainly the lungs and lymph glands. Neurosarcoidosis can lead to seizures, and there have been rare reports of associated autoimmune hemolytic anemia and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: This term encompasses a group of disorders that cause blood vessel inflammation which can lead to a wide range of symptoms including pericardial effusion and, less commonly, seizures and psychiatric symptoms. Hemolytic anemia and synovitis could also be present based on the specific type of vasculitis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can involve internal organs leading to pericardial effusion, but other symptoms listed are less common.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This rare genetic disorder causes the immune system to produce an excess of white blood cells, leading to autoimmune problems including hemolysis. Rarely, it may cause symptoms affecting the nervous system or lead to pericardial effusion.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (with secondary health issues causing the physical symptoms)
Chronic viral infection (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Primary Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Primary brain tumors can cause seizures due to the pressure they exert on brain tissues. Although not directly causing hemorrhoids, the overall health stress, including possible mobility issues and medication side effects, could contribute to such conditions.

diagnoses.name: Cirrhosis
diagnoses.description: Cirrhosis can lead to portal hypertension, contributing to the development of hemorrhoids. It can also cause thrombocytopenia due to splenic sequestration. Advanced stages might lead to hepatic encephalopathy, causing issues with attention and potentially focal seizures.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This is an autoimmune disorder that increases the risk of thromboembolic events and can cause thrombocytopenia. Neurological manifestations can include seizures, and the systemic nature of the syndrome could indirectly affect vision and cognitive functions like attention.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Leukemia can cause thrombocytopenia due to bone marrow infiltration, leading to an increased risk of bleeding, including hemorrhoids. It can also cause seizures if there is CNS involvement. Attention deficit and difficulty focusing vision could be related to CNS involvement or the general effects of cancer.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: MS is a chronic illness that affects the brain and spinal cord, leading to symptoms like difficulty focusing vision and potential cognitive impacts such as attention deficit. Seizures are not a hallmark symptom but can occur in some patients.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE can cause a wide range of symptoms, including seizures due to CNS involvement and thrombocytopenia. Thromboembolic disease is also a risk due to antiphospholipid antibodies. Neurological symptoms can include cognitive dysfunction, potentially affecting attention.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: This is a rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, which could potentially explain thromboembolic disease and thrombocytopenia. Neurological involvement can lead to seizures, and various symptoms could indirectly affect attention and vision.

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)
diagnoses.description: HUS is characterized by the triad of acute renal failure, hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia which could indirectly contribute to hemorrhoid development through vascular damage and could potentially have neurological outcomes, including seizures or other CNS effects.

diagnoses.name: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)
diagnoses.description: TTP involves thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, which may lead to thromboembolic complications, potentially contributing to seizures. Its impact on the brain can affect cognitive functions like attention.

diagnoses.name: Vascular Dementia
diagnoses.description: While primarily associated with cognitive decline, vascular dementia can present with a wide array of symptoms depending on the area of the brain affected, including potential seizures, thrombocytopenia due to associated cardiovascular diseases, and difficulty with vision and attention.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.description: A common disorder in which there are repetitive episodes of complete or partial obstruction of the upper airway during sleep.
A long-term condition where stomach contents come back up into the esophagus resulting in either symptoms or complications. It can lead to vomiting and might contribute to dysgeusia.
A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, tinnitus, and progressive hearing loss, along with potential nausea and vomiting.
Long-standing disease of the kidneys leading to renal failure. Can cause cysts in the kidneys and may result in dysgeusia due to toxin buildup.
Benign growths that can occur in various parts of the body and may not be symptomatic unless they interfere with normal organ function.
A condition that affects a woman's hormone levels, leading to the development of ovarian cysts. It is unrelated to the other symptoms but may be considered if cysts were specified without a location.

Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that may be benign or cancerous. Can cause vomiting, tinnitus if affecting certain brain parts, and possibly affect taste or obstructive symptoms depending on location and size.
Overproduction of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland, which can lead to various systemic symptoms including dysgeusia.
A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period. It can lead to dysgeusia and contribute to the development of OSA.

A primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent headaches that are moderate to severe. Typically, the headaches affect one half of the head, are pulsating in nature, and can be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light or sound.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, which may cause complications such as chest pain. It may also lead to an enlarged spleen that can affect the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can cause an increase in white blood cells, which can lead to an enlarged spleen and increased susceptibility to infections. Symptomatic individuals may experience fatigue, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer that begins in the lymphatic system. The disease can cause lymphadenitis, chest pain, fever, and increased susceptibility to infections due to a compromised immune system.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of the lymphatic system. It can cause the lymph nodes to enlarge beyond their normal size (lymphadenitis), lead to increased susceptibility to infections, and manifest with symptoms such as fatigue, fever, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the immune system produces too many white blood cells. This can lead to an increased risk of infections, lymphadenitis, and possibly symptoms related to autoimmunity like alopecia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) severely damages the immune system over time, leading to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). This can manifest in various symptoms including increased susceptibility to infections, lymphadenitis, and chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and potential damage across organs, including the skin (alopecia), joints, and possibly heart (chest pain). Patients may also have an increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that mainly affects joints but can also have systemic effects such as increased susceptibility to infection and, though less commonly, lymphadenopathy and pulmonary issues that could explain chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection mainly affecting the lungs, but can also affect other parts of the body. It can cause chest pain, lymphadenitis, and significantly weaken the immune system, increasing susceptibility to more infections.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. It can cause lymphadenitis, chest pain, and potentially lead to an impaired immune response.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.description: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.details: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken your blood, slowing its flow, which may cause fatigue, and in some cases, may contribute to chronic pain due to poor circulation.

diagnoses.description: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.details: A rare bone marrow cancer that disrupts your body's normal production of blood cells, potentially leading to polycythemia. It can cause extensive scarring in your bone marrow, leading to severe anemia, fatigue, and spleen enlargement.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.details: Chronic kidney disease can lead to a buildup of fluid and waste in the body, causing fatigue, and in advanced stages, can contribute to the development of polycythemia due to increased production of erythropoietin.

diagnoses.description: Heart Failure
diagnoses.details: Heart failure can lead to fluid accumulation in the body, causing fatigue and can be associated with polycythemia as the body attempts to compensate for poor oxygenation.

diagnoses.description: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder that causes chronic inflammation of the joints and other parts of the body. It could correlate with chronic back pain and fatigue, and in some cases, may have systemic effects leading to periodontal disease.

diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.details: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. It often leads to fatigue and can also contribute to a variety of symptoms and disorders, including polycythemia and chronic pain conditions.

diagnoses.description: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.details: Sleep apnea can lead to chronic fatigue due to disturbed sleep. The resulting low oxygen levels at night can stimulate the body to produce more red blood cells, leading to secondary polycythemia.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Inflammation
diagnoses.details: Chronic inflammation can be associated with a wide range of health issues including polycythemia (as a response to increased need for oxygen transport), fatigue, chronic back pain, and potentially contribute to the severity of periodontal disease.

diagnoses.description: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.details: A rare, genetic disorder that causes severe swelling, usually in the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway. It doesn't explain all symptoms but could be relevant, especially in combination with other disorders.

diagnoses.description: Secondary Erythrocytosis
diagnoses.details: Secondary erythrocytosis is when your body makes too many red blood cells, in response to chronic low oxygen levels or, rarely, abnormal production of erythropoietin. It could be linked with chronic back pain, fatigue, and in some contexts, with periodontal disease due to associated inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with dry eyes and dry mouth, which can accompany lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes) as the immune system attacks glands that produce tears and saliva.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, dry eyes, and neurological manifestations leading to irritability.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) can lead to the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), causing a wide range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy, and potentially autoimmune manifestations leading to dry eyes and irritability due to nervous system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Sarcoidosis can cause lymphadenopathy and has been associated with eye and nervous system problems.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also involve extra-articular tissues, including the eyes (leading to dryness) and lymphoid tissues causing lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes. These cells are in the lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, and other parts of the body. Lymphoma may present with lymphadenitis and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis which primarily affects the lungs but can also affect the lymphatic system, causing lymphadenitis, and potentially leading to systemic symptoms such as dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs after an allogeneic tissue transplant in which the donated bone marrow or peripheral blood stem cells view the recipient's body as foreign and attack the body. It can cause dry eyes, lymphadenopathy, and affect the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Meibomian Gland Dysfunction (MGD)
diagnoses.description: A commonly encountered eyelid margin disease causing dry eyes. Although it doesn't directly cause lymphadenopathy or dysautonomia, it could be part of systemic inflammatory syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)/Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (ME)
diagnoses.description: A complex chronic illness characterized by extreme fatigue, pain, and a range of other symptoms including lymphadenopathy, and potentially dysautonomias and irritability due to nervous system involvement.

diagnoses: Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)
Spinal Disorders (e.g., Herniated Disc, Degenerative Disc Disease)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) - including Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur suddenly after exposure to an allergen. Symptoms include swelling (angioedema), low blood pressure (hypotension), and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction that leads to sneezing, runny nose (rhinorrhea), and itching (pruritus), often caused by airborne allergens such as pollen, dust, or animal dander.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria
diagnoses.description: Also known as hives, this condition is characterized by raised, itchy welts on the skin and can be accompanied by angioedema, pruritus, and sometimes vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition that causes repeated episodes of severe swelling. Symptoms can include angioedema, abdominal pain, and in severe cases, life-threatening airway obstruction.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food. Symptoms can include vomiting, hypotension, angioedema, and pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Drug Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction to a medication. Symptoms can vary widely and may include rash, hives, itching (pruritus), swelling (angioedema), and in severe cases, anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A skin rash caused by contact with a certain substance. Symptoms can include itching, red skin, and in some cases, vomiting if the reaction is severe.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions related to the inappropriate release of mast cell mediators. Symptoms can include hypotension, vomiting, pruritus, angioedema, and rhinorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Insect Sting Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to insect stings, which can cause symptoms ranging from local swelling and itching to anaphylaxis with hypotension, vomiting, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Latex Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to natural rubber latex. Symptoms can range from skin irritation, rhinorrhea, and pruritus to more severe reactions like anaphylaxis.

diagnoses: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation with infection

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe head pain followed or accompanied by sensory disturbances such as flashes of light, blind spots, tingling in the arms and legs, nausea, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including but not limited to severe, debilitating headaches, nausea, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound. Unlike migraine with aura, it does not include visual and sensory disturbances prior to the headache.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: Severe, recurring headaches on one side of the head, typically around the eye, accompanied by other symptoms such as redness of the eye, sweating, nasal congestion or runny nose. They are called 'cluster headaches' because they tend to happen in groups or clusters.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headaches
diagnoses.description: The most common type of headache, characterized by a dull, aching sensation all over the head rather than throbbing pain in one spot. Some individuals may also experience sensitivity to light or sound.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke', a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke, such as temporary numbness or weakness on one side of the body, slurred speech, or blindness in one or both eyes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that can cause symptoms including numbness, weakness, balance issues, and trouble with vision. Specific visual phenomena like scintillation may be indicative of optic neuritis, a common early sign of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause a variety of symptoms depending on its location. Symptoms may include headaches, nausea, vomiting, vision problems, numbness or tingling in the limbs, and cognitive or personality changes.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. It is a serious condition that can cause severe headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, stiffness of the neck, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from poor blood flow to the back of the brain, which can cause symptoms like dizziness, double vision, slurred speech, imbalance, and 'drop attacks'.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, causing brain cells to die. Symptoms can include headache, paralysis or numbness of the face, arms, or legs, trouble speaking or understanding speech, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses: Toxic effects of medications (e.g., aminoglycosides, salicylates)
Vertigo (BPPV - benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, Meniere's disease)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Connective tissue disease (e.g., Sjögren's syndrome, Rheumatoid arthritis)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by symptoms like skin rashes, joint pain, and fatigue. The annular polycyclic rash and nasal ulcers are specifically associated with cutaneous lupus erythematosus, a subtype focused on the skin.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. It's characterized by the formation of granulomas, clusters of immune cells. Skin manifestations like annular polycyclic rash and postinflammatory dyspigmentation can occur, and lymphopenia can be part of the immunological presentation.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also involve other parts of the body. It can cause skin changes and, in rare cases, lung involvement might lead to symptoms similar to those of pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease known for its distinctive skin rash and muscle weakness. The rash often presents as reddish or purplish and can be polycyclic. Postinflammatory dyspigmentation can occur in the skin's healing process.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. The disease can lead to numerous signs and symptoms that may seem unrelated at first, including mouth sores, genital sores, inflammation inside the eye, and skin problems like the described rash.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by tick bites. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including a characteristic bull's-eye rash, joint pain, and, in later stages, possible heart and neurological issues.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that affects the skin, leading to the development of red, scaly patches. Certain forms of psoriasis can present with annular polycyclic rashes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune rheumatic disease characterized by hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can also cause vascular issues, leading to symptoms such as pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, this infectious disease can lead to significant lymphopenia, pharyngitis, fever, and fatigue. Skin rashes and liver involvement can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. It can cause lymphopenia due to abnormal white blood cell production, and skin manifestations can sometimes occur.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
